reviewText:
THIS GAME.

THIS ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•ING GAME.

BUYING THIS GAME WAS ONE OF THE WORST MISTAKES I EVER MADE.


I started this game up expecting to have a good time, as I did with the other Fallout games. I'd played Fallout 1, and I'd heard from almost everyone that Fallout 2 was FAR superior. I throroughly enjoyed Fallout 1, but my main problem with it was that the game was timed, and practically forced you to rush through it. Because of this, I felt as though my experience with the game was cut short. The main thing I was looking for when I started playing Fallout 2 was a lengthier game that would allow me to explore and progress at my own pace.

I got more than I could have ever hoped for.

The game started out slow, much like many other RPGs, and frankly, it was a bit boring for the first few hours. But I knew from my previous experiences that Fallout games only get better as you progress. I made it through the first few areas, and started getting a feel for how things worked, finding plenty of new quests, etc. It was becoming rather enjoyable, then I got the car, which would allow me to carry more things, and explore the wasteland with much more ease. It was very exciting, almost like getting my first car all over again. And at that point I was hooked.

Everything from that point on is a bit of a blur, I remember traveling from city to city, back and forth, looking for every quest I could possibly find. The process of finding better and better gear for my three companions was addicting, the process of ensuring the prosperity of all the settlements was addicting, the atmosphere is addicting, becoming famous for various reasons across the wasteland was addicting, the fact that the game goes into so much detail and lets you influence the way things play out was addicting. EVERYTHING ABOUT THIS GAME IS ADDICTING!

I couldn't help it, hours and hours of my life were being sucked away, and there was nothing I could to about it except keep playing. IT WAS AMAZING.

The final toll was a little over 66 hours for me. And that was all spent on a single playthrough. When I FINALLY beat the game, I felt a feeling of happiness and satisfaction that I haven't felt in YEARS. But most of all, I felt an overwhelming sense of FREEDOM. NO LONGER WAS I SHACKLED BY ITS IMMENSE QUALITY, BY ITS SHEER BEAUTY. I will never play this game for the first time again, that makes me both relieved and depressed. Depressed, because this game is phenomenal, because it is one of the best games I ever played. But relieved, because I will never lose that many hours that quickly ever again.

This game is a true gem. It is an incredible, immersive experience even by today's standards, and in fact, sh√Øts all over most modern RPGs.

That's the problem, though, this game is TOO GOOD. DO NOT PLAY THIS GAME UNLESS YOU HAVE ABSOLUTELY NOTHING TO LOSE.




Now if you'll excuse me, I'm gonna start my evil playthough.

reviewText:
Destroys everything, one of the greatest pieces of art ever created, Fallout 2 is an RPG in which you play a tribesman who is tasked to find and return a device to his village known as the G.E.C.K (which is a piece of technology that is able to revitalize areas of a post-nuclear wasteland, transforming dead, irradiated soil into viable land suitable for farming) to save his people from famine. The plot is subtle and a great break from all the melodramatic, save the universe type ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• most games consist of.

Fallout 2, like the first, gives you a large, brutal and unforgiving world to traverse at your own risk, full of genuinely fascinating locations and extremely interesting characters to interact with; from scientists who give mutated scorpions chems to their increase intelligence, talking plants and a highly intelligent and articulate Deathclaw, there are tons of geniusly fantastic, memorable characters to interact with through-out and even though Fallout 2 doesn't always take itself too seriously and is sometimes outright comical the game still portrays a grim, cruel and extremely immersive world like no other.

Fallout 2 features some of the finest role playing out there, with tons of meaningful choices and consequences through-out which question your ethics and morality on a far deeper scale than just simply being the good / bad guy. The quests you recieve in Fallout 2 are diverse and often offer multiple ways in which you can complete them, some ways which were not even intended by the developers, there is just so much freedom of choice here that is completely non-existent in 'RPGs' today.

The character building is brilliant and has a ton of depth, every little stat directly affects how your game plays out, being highly intelligent with the personality of a brick or being a knucklehead with the charisma of a dictator will deeply affect how NPCs interact with you. There are so many choices to make in character building that have huge, meaningful impacts on the world around you that multiple playthroughs are essential to experience what this masterpiece has to offer.

The visuals at first glance may seem bland and out-dated but the art direction is beyond brilliant and is complimented by believable, excellent world design and an insanely thick atmosphere - this doesn't feel like videogame world nor like it was designed to be one, rather an actual post-apocalyptic place.

The sound effects are absolutely spot on. The ambient, non-intrusive music through-out is fantastic and adds a lot to the atmosphere and the voiced dialogue is pretty well done.

Fallout 2's combat is turn-based and offers a ton of depth, giving you the opportunity to use a tactical approach rather than just mindlessly clicking away like in many of todays so-called RPG's - I do however encounter frustration with not being able to control friendly AI in combat and as a result get shot in the back and watching friendly AI running at an isolated enemy instead of backing up your character who then gets outnumbered and killed is rage-inducing to say the least, these flaws only occur right in the beginning until you get used to pathing and such but rather big flaws non-the-less.

Overall Fallout 2, along with Baldur's Gate, Darklands and Planescape Torment are the pinnacle of RPGs in every regard and will probably remain that way until the end of time judging by how far the genre has declined since. You can't call yourself a fan of RPGs until you have experienced these absolute masterpieces, if you're interested in playing Fallout 1 or 2 for the first time and haven't played anything of the sort before I'd advise a lot of patience in the early stages which by judging from some of the negative reviews is too much to ask for some.

This is a mandatory experience for anyone who loves videogames, experiences like this simply don't exist anymore.

While Fallout 2's wacky humor and ridiculous references to things like Monty Python and the Holy Grail might not be for absolutely everyone, it does have a much larger world with much more content than Fallout 1 that is, in my opinion at the very least, of equal quality as it's predecessor. The story shares some similarity to the first game, as you play a tribal descendant of the Vault Dweller, sent out to find a device that will save your dying village of Arroyo from famine and disease.

The world, though, feels much larger, showing far more signs of development over the years. Old towns like the LA Boneyard and Junktown have disappeared off the map, replaced with or absorbed into new, more solidly established places like the New California Republic, an evolution of the town of Shady Sands, a San Francisco Chinatown populated by chinese refugees and even New Reno, a city of vice and sin populated by casinos, porn theaters, drug dealers, and gangs of post-nuclear mafiosos all going at each other's throats for control of the city.

Mechanically, Fallout 2 tightens up a lot of stuff from the first game. Most immediately noticeable are things like a Take All" button in container menus

reviewText:
If there is a genre of games which I value and play above all others it's first person shooters. Especially competitive MP FPS games like UT, Quake, Counter Strike etc. However every once in a while comes a game that isn't a part of those genres and it's so bloody good that it makes an exception to my preference. This recommendation is for Fallout 1 and 2 which are easily bought in a cheap value pack. Without a doubt they stand as some of the greatest games ever made. Even if they are technologically way behind the times, the concept idea and execution are so well done that this become one of the biggest benchmarks for role playing games in general.

These games are simple to explain, it's a free roaming massive quest based role playing game. You start the game with entire world open to you, hardly any restrictions and it's up to you to what happens. There are absurd amount of choices in pretty much everything. Make a character that is a gunslinger, sniper, brute using melee weapons, a silver tonged diplomat, a ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• who can only communicate via grunts and hardly understandable shouts,a slaver, evil to the core son of a ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•. it's all open to you from start. The character creation portion is extensive, complicated and delightful to how much you can plan out for your game. This is followed numerous ways to solve problems. Almost every problem has multiple solutions, ranging from taking different sides (pleasing or ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• off factions), violent approach, diplomatic approach you name it. A person won't help you with something you just take your gun and kill them, then face the consequences. Game is really harsh, anything rash and dumb can easily end up with game over.

One huge praise to the choice presented to the player is the adult theme that isn't dumbed down (unlike the more recent Fallout 3 and NV(though NV to less extent)). You can become a porn star, ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• yourself out for services and persuasion, you can kill children and be labeled as a Childkiller. Everything you do reflects your standing in the world and how NPCs look at you.

Another big praise is how humor is incorporated into this wacky, grim post apocaliptic world. Expect several monty python references and spoofs.It's seamless and fitting. It's amazing how well such wacky humor incorporated into dark games such as these two.

If there are downsides it's that vanilla games are rather buggy. I recommend Killap's unoffical patch/restoration project for fallout 2 and the appropriate patches for fallout 1. Check No Mutants Allowed for patches. Get the resolution patch as well. This way you can upscale the resolution to more modern standard.

I could sit here all day and write about the insane amount of cool things to do in this game, but that's better to be experienced in person. Do yourself a favor and if you like RPG games where you are not shoehorned into a path, play these game. They are most certainly some of the best you will ever play.

reviewText:
Just over a decade ago, life was simpler and more frivolous, so every fictional discovery was fascinating and entertaining. It was in that simple, mid-teenage life, that I dug Fallout 2 out of a fortunate coincidence. A disc copy of the game, in a modest gaming magazine, to whose cover it was poorly attached. It seemed interesting enough, and with little knowledge of cRPGs or English, I went home and gave it a try. Boy, was I enthralled by this game. A game which would, about ten years later, still be the most cherished piece of gaming I have ever experienced.

Fallout 2 ventures deep into the dark territories of humour and morbidity. Not many have the grit for its atmosphere, inauspicious and heavy as it is, its dense soundtrack that evinces feelings of gloomy solitude and decadence; exactly the vibe you have got to be in when playing any Fallout title, for that matter. Back when I first tried it, I would engage in conflicts between the curiosity to explore its narrative and the uneasiness caused by that very atmosphere, even after having previously and briefly tried Planescape: Torment - an equally dense game. Fortunately for me, I got past that.

Provided that you can also overcome such uneasiness, you've got an unparallelled RPG challenge ahead of you. Fallout 2, very much like its predecessor, is beautifully written, and cleverly designed in a way that connects your actions to the realities and contextual changes of Northern California as you go. The turn-based combat is typical late-90s cRPG gold. The S.P.E.C.I.A.L role-playing system, a jewel derived from Gurps, offers you that edge of character construction and skill management that makes a bonafide RPG pleasurable. The post-apocalyptic setting and aesthetics, built on the famous premise of the Divergence - the historical fragmentation in which the fictional linearity of the game took a different course from that of our world in the heat of the Cold War, leaving the former with that futuristic-50s style -, renders Fallout's identity unique and typically dark humoured. Its characters are deeply unpredictable and credible, especially the companions, much more mature than those of the previous installment (with all due respect to the likes of Ian and Dogmeat). The game leaves that bitter feeling of longing in the player's mouth should they pass away or have to be left behind for some reason. Each companion adds to the player's enterprise, each has their own story, each has their own passions and motivations. And flaws.

Fallout 2 appeals to multiple audiences. Those looking for an RPG; those looking for a post-apocalyptic piece; those looking for a story-driven game; those looking for open-world dynamic narratives; those looking for a demi-horror title; and so forth. While it may not touch some of these categories in depth, it is a game that brings them all to a perfect harmony. Fallout 1

Fallout 2 is set 80 years after the events of Fallout 1 and you are the grandchild of the 1st games's protaganist the vault dweller you are the chosen one of your village Arroyo tasked with finding a G.E.C.K to help save your village.

Gameplay

General overview of Fallout 2

Fallout 2 is a timeless classic of the Fallout franchise and for those who consider themselves die hard fans of the fallout series you should get this game also if you do get the game also download the resteration patch from the No mutants allowed forum it adds cut content into the game and fixes bugs and generally makes the game better overall

Note: In no way in this review am i hating on Fallout 3 i think Fallout 3 is a brilliant game and i recommend it to anyone but i do not think of it as a Fallout game that stays true to the originals like Fallout New Vegas did

reviewText:
Fallout 2 is a game that went under my games to play radar for far too long, mostly because when it came out I wasn't even   in primary school yet. I'm typically not the biggest fan of this kind of post-apocalyptic setting, in fact this is the only one I like. I owe my discovering this masterpiece entirely to the streamlined fallout experience by Bethesda and later Obsidian.

I found the first dungeon to be ruthless my first playthrough, it took me a reload or two before I managed to survive the initial trial and start the main quest. When I emerged into the wasteland of Fallout 2, I was a bit intimidated, every direction on the map had opened up to me. The main quest giver did point me in the direction of a nearby town, but I wanted to see how far south I could go, maybe discover a cool town or two. Nope, I just ended up with plenty of bullets in my corpse.

I decide to not go south when I reload and instead go to the town that the elder directed me to, this is where I lost interest initially. I ended up not in the mood to read any of the dialogs that would've pointed me in the right direction and instead gave up. A few months pass and on a whim I decide to reload my save and see if I can't make any headway in game. After I did a few side quests I really started to enjoy myself, the battle system I found unforgiving started to feel a little rewarding, and I kept going.

I am a little sad however, I'm nearing the final content of the game and I'm trying my darndest to make my remaining hours on my character, the powerfist wielding warrior Gertrude, last as long as possible.

PROS:
-The game has aged well in my opinion, the graphics may not look as sharp as some people may desire, but the game is  still entirely playable.
-The combat is very fun after the initial slow burn, I'd say about level 5 is where it took off for me.
-The characters have been very fun, I can recall most of the characters I've run into in Fallout 2, the same can't be said of Fallout 3 or New Vegas (granted they each had a few good characters).
-Tons of content, I've spent a good 30-40 hours on my current character and still find new quests.

CONS:
-The game is from the late 90's and has technical limitations because of this (Combat can be very slow when a large number of characters are engaged in battle)
-You cannot reload in combat when it is not your turn to move, this doesn't sound too bad but in large battles where you try to keep your companions alive it can be a little bothersome.
-There is a time limit in game for how long you can play, it's an unfortunate technical issue, however you have about 13 in game years until you are forced to play a new character (my current character is on year 3 near the end of the game)

Final thoughts on the game:
This is honestly the best game I've played in past years, it makes me yearn for games that don't constantly hold my hand. Every mistake I make is punished, every good decision I make is rewarded. The myriad of companions in game really made my experience that much better (barring when Sulik would sit in doorways, blocking my only exit). If I had to give this game a number score it'd probably be an 8 or 9 out of 10. There is no perfect game, and this game certainly has quite  a large number of faults, but this is the most fun I've had with a game since my initial Dark Souls playthrough.

reviewText:
Originally released by in 1998, I never really had the chance to play Fallout 2, mostly due to the fact I was too busy being born. Having got wrapped up into the Fallout 3 hype train, I became rather enthralled in the franchise itself. So, several years later, I picked it up and‚Ä¶

...in an attempt to not color my already vibrant opinion of the nearly twenty year old title to nothing but what can be considered felatio, let me just be a bit hypercritical about the game. The most glaring ‚Äúproblem‚Äù is what Fallout: New Vegas suffers from, by basically being the same game twice, effectively Fallout 2.0. While it didn‚Äôt work to the determent of the more modern entries, it hurts the overall visual experience with the sprites being rather noticeably polarized. Most are ripped straight from the original, built by pixels and with limited frame to frame animation. Then you have the newer 3D rendered sprites with smoother animation, creating an immersion breaking experience.

Thankfully, these sprites don‚Äôt really appear in the same cell often, but when they do it is noticeably. Another problem they never fixed was the ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•ING INVENTORY UI! Its clumsy and finicky at best, with the mouse cursor deciding the change sensitivity like a pregnant women. You will work around it eventually, but it just infuriates me how this aspect was never fixed. Its horrid but manages to get the job done.

Getting down on my knees, everything else is, the world, leveling system, character's, weapon variety and quest are, to put it broadly, ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•ING FANTASTIC. While the characters are a tad uninspired and two dimensional, and the story banal, Fallout 2 is possibly one of the best Western RPGs ever made. The leveling system grants satisfaction, managing to maintain this by having ‚ÄúPerks‚Äù(effectively permanent stat or combat boosts) that you receive every other level. You can‚Äôt help but wanting to progress with the prospect of nearly sawing men in half with not much but as dainty slap.

The world can be summarized as a sour salted candy advertised as extremely so, its daunting at first and WILL kick you ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• once you pop it in you gob, but will eventually become remarkable sweet. Southern California is huge, being exceptionally difficult during the early game but incredibly rewarding later down the line. The only problem I have with the world is the lack of variety, but I feel the questing can make up for this.

I feel developers can live or die by the hand holding die. Choosing to do so makes the game a breeze, and choosing not to has the potential to make progress come to a screeching halt. Fallout 2 gives you just enough information to get on with the question without some patronizing arrow pointing out where to go. And can even have you thinking about solutions for the rare puzzle here and there. Quest are satisfying and varied to an insane degree.

Fallout 2 might possibly be one of the few games in which you likely won‚Äôt see every weapon or outcome. If you ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• up, you ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•ed up and there is no turning back, with some things being consequently cut off. Prompting actual thought and replay-ability, I love this idea. The weapons on the other hand, are insanely variant. Its not the fact that a quest outcome closes them off from you, it's the fact there are so ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•ing many that you're unlikely to even find them all. Whether this works for the games prosperity or detriment.

Regardless, with its negatives and positives in check, Fallout 2 is one of the greatest title I have ever played. Even with its missteps, no matter how small, they pale to what the game does right. Of fantastic value, Fallout 2 is a must buy title, no matter its age.

reviewText:
I got my first taste of Fallout with Fallout 3, and I immediately fell in love. I couldn't think of a better game out there. And then Fallout New Vegas came along. And I'll be honest, I was not a fan. Not in the least. First glance was a desolate land that had more punishing combat and a bizarre ammo system. Fast forward a couple months and I decide to give it another go. For some reason this second foray really opened my eyes and I had a blast with the changed up combat that made you think, and the ammo system that gave you more flexability. And once I started playing I discovered something even more miraculous: the writing. Fallout New Vegas had a more believable environment, better characters, better writing. It simply felt more thought out. And looking into its development I discovered that it had some of the creators of the original Fallouts working on it. So I had to give the originals a try.

So I started with Fallout 1, of course. I bought the pack off of steam and installed it with a gusto. Finally the 5 minute process ended and I delightfully booted up the game, only to have a brilliant rainbow engulf the screen. Great. So I do some quick interneting and download the hi-res pack for Fallout 1 and Killap's Restoration Pack for Fallout 2 in order to plan ahead. Fallout 1 started, and I hit the ground running. My first isometric RPG! Woo-hoo! I immediately fell flat on my face, being killed by rats. I learned my first Fallout lesson: It's okay to run. So after hours of such trial and error I finally completed my game of Fallout 1, and was eager to continue the adventure in Fallout 2.

If you have made it this far, good lord. On to Fallout 2.

Fallout 2, to put it mildly, blew me away. Though the first level was obnoxious as hell. That Temple deserves to burn. Regardless, I pushed forward and entered the world proper. And it was glorious. Everything good from Fallout 1, Fallout 2 has. And then it expands on those. And THEN adds even more. I could do anything here. The world was truely my playground. I could, and did, do anything I wanted. The combat is incredibly punishing, forcing you to make some truely tactical decisions, however it just makes every win that much more satisfying. The dialogue is witty, dark, a tad campy at times, and heartbreaking. The depths of depravity that is portrayed is mindboggling in the modern game sphere. GTA has nothing on this. Additionally I simply love the Enclave. Probably shouldn't, but I do. I really didn't do this game justice at all, did I? When it came down to it I didn't know what to say.

Buy this, install it, download the Restoration Pack, install that, play the game, never stop.

reviewText:
Fallout 2 is the sequel to one of my favorite RPG's of all time and it does a superb job of the lifting the mantle of the original Fallout even if it does have it's flaws.

Fallout 2 sets you as the descendant of the original Vault Dweller who we now learned founded a small tribe near the Californian coast following the events of the original. This tribe has now fallen on hard times and as the direct descendant of the Vault Dweller you are charged with going out into the world and finding a mythical Vault device known as the G.E.C.K. This device, the elder of your village believe, have the power to turn the part of the wasteland into an utopia and ensure the tribe's future.

You start off the game with a somewhat lackluster tutorial that introduces you to the basic elements of the game however it is only once you leave this initial area and are ready to depart your childhood village for the first time that the game truly comes into it's own. The massive world map at your feet with no restrictions on where to go and who to see.

The mechanics are much the same as the original. Isometric turn-based role playing game using the S.P.E.C.I.A.L system for character development. It is however in the open nature of the game that you find it's soul. Made a female character with high charisma? You might be able to charm, or sleep, your way past several encounters. Made a character with incredibly low intelligence? All of the sudden your dialog responses are just various grunts and the people you encounter will treat you as a freak of nature.

Even most of the storyline can be skipped if you know where to go and almost every task you are given in the game can be solved in a myriad of ways, many options not even becoming apparent to you unless you have the needed skills or made some particular choices beforehand.

The game does have some shortcomings. The 4th wall breaking that was rare in the original are much more commonplace and several characters and areas just feel out of place with the rest of the game.
New Reno in particular, a gambling town complete with mafia families fighting for control and a working porn studio takes you completely out of the game and makes for a rather disappointing experience.

Fallout 2 has all the qualities that made the original one of the greatest RPG's ever and it improves on many aspects of it with better companion AI and a much larger map. It's faults however do weight heavily and keep it from surpassing it's predecessor. It is still one of the greatest RPG's ever to be made and if you are a fan of open ended RPG games and intelligent story and dialog then it should be a definite purchase.

reviewText:
This is it.  This is the game the cemented the Fallout universe and is considered by many the pinnacle of the series until New Vegas.  This is the game the truly cements the core story of the franchise and takes the seeds planted in FO1 and grows them to fruitiion.  In that process, they helped open up countless routes for storylines for the rest of the series.

Some folks complain that now a game like this feels dated.  I would do my best to compel to you put aside that sort of metric when it comes to assessing the greatness of a game.  With some patience and thought ,which is so often taken out of today popular games, you can grasp hold of what seems at first glance, a copmlicated system for conveying your player character through the in-game universe.

The routes you take, many encounters, and many other aspects of the game are so open, so huge, that you could play through many times and still find different things. There are so many hidden routes, items, quests, etc and so many ways to play the game it's impossible to describe them all here(smart, tech savvy character or a  brawler or a dimwit?  you can play them all and they all change the game)

This game is a classic for a reason and is the gold standard by which other similar games should be judged.

Buy it, play it, and understand where one of the greatest game franchises ever got much of it's spark.

Do it now.

reviewText:
War. War never changes.

The end of the world occurred pretty much as we had predicted. Too many humans, not enough space or resources to go around. The details are trivial and pointless, the reasons, as always, purely human ones.

The earth was nearly wiped clean of life. A great cleansing, an atomic spark struck by human hands, quickly raged out of control. Spears of nuclear fire rained from the skies. Continents were swallowed in flames and fell beneath the boiling oceans. Humanity was almost extinguished, their spirits becoming part of the background radiation that blanketed the earth.

A quiet darkness fell across the planet, lasting many years. Few survived the devastation. Some had been fortunate enough to reach safety, taking shelter in great underground vaults. When the great darkness passed, these vaults opened, and their inhabitants emerged to begin their lives again.

One of the northern tribes claims they are descended from one such Vault. They hold that their founder and ancestor, one known as the Vault Dweller
date:
once saved the world from a great evil. According to their legend, this evil arose in the far south. It corrupted all it touched, twisting men inside, turning them into beasts. Only through the bravery of this Vault Dweller was the evil destroyed. But in so doing, he lost many of his friends and suffered greatly, sacrificing much of himself to save the world.

When at last he returned to the home he had fought so hard to protect, he was cast out. Exiled. In confronting that which they feared, he had become something else in their eyes...and no longer their champion.

Forsaken by his people, he strode into the wasteland. He traveled far to the north, until he came to the great canyons. There, he founded a small village, Arroyo, where he lived out the rest of his years. And so, for a generation since its founding, Arroyo has lived in peace, its canyons sheltering it from the outside world. It is home. Your home.

But the scars left by the war have not yet healed. And the Earth has not forgotten.

reviewText:
The hype is spot on for this classic, it actually is not blind nostalgia when it is said that this game allows for far more role-playing than every other video game in existence.

Fallout 2 is not bound by modern day game design limitations and rules, it does things modern games are afraid to do.  It was designed by the most talented game studio of all time, Black Isle Studios, with much of the excellence being on showcase in Planescape: Torment which was released the following year.  Largely a different kind of excellence, but both games are so much more original and limitless than anything today.  Everything you do in Fallout 2 leads to some reaction, big or small, but usually somewhat realistic.  When playing the game you have to think twice about what you say and how you act.

Keep talking to someone who doesn't want to be bothered, and there may actually be consequences.  Sneak around in the open and people will question you.  Walk around with a weapon equipped in certain places and you may find yourself being fired upon.  Throw away First Citizen Lynette's trust and say goodbye to Vault City forever.  Become a boxing champion in New Reno and you will be famous and respected in that area, with the townsfolk calling you Champ" most of the time.  Play as a cold blooded
date: ruthless killer and you will be feared and certain quests will open up to you while others will become unavailable.  Finish the main quest in a positive way and you will be hailed a hero in most places.  Play as a low intelligence character and watch the whole game transform appropriately (look it up on YouTube if you must).  The list goes on
recommended: these are just some examples of the attention to detail in Fallout 2 that no other game exhibits.\n\nFallout 2 is also a very good satire
hoursPlayed: less serious than its modern counterparts.  If you've only played Fallout 3 and Fallout 4 then you've barely experienced Fallout.  New Vegas is an impressive sequel however

reviewText:
I'd rather confidenly say this is the best Fallout game in the series so far. All of them have great atmosphere and mood, but they also have their fair share of stupid mistakes or just plain lack of certain qualities. Fallout 2 eludes most of the failings of its predecessor and its successors and stands strong on its own as well.

It provides enough variety and character to feel full and alive, while staying true to the mood and maintaining the bar of quality at a reasonable level. Just as importantly, it maintains a very decent level of reactivity and non-linearity, and offers maybe not perfect but seriously flexible mechanics. It also introduces the best plot twist of the whole series. So all in all, I'd call it the purest and the most successful execution of the Fallout concept so far.

Even though I would love it to have more of the desperate and mysterious mood of the very beginning of Fallout 1, the vast pretty enviroments of Fallout 3 and the tasteful characterization of New Vegas.

reviewText:
The masterpiece of all rpgs, Fallout 2 yet its practicly a son of wasteland, this game is worth the weight, worth getting rid of your nagging girlfriend/wife and worth quitting that business monkey job, you don't need any of that anyway! all you need is a fresh nuka-cola and some fallout 2.

Now in a few weeks is mah birthdays with planning to buy wasteland 2 I decide to write my personal expierence and opinon on this game.

Why you ask? I will tell you my experience.

Here you are born in a tribal village in the wasteland of america,  your home where your ancestor known as the vault dweller of V13 was exiled from his overseer due to the fear of spreading diseases and radiation inside the vault towards the pure dwellers, your ancestor did nothing wrong but saved his people from being forced out of the vault into the cruel wasteland due to a dying water supply and being raided by monsterous mutants of the Master's army, he walked north and north to find a tribal village on the wasteland... in present time, you discover your home village is dying.. brahmin are dying, children sick with diseases. everything was starting to fall apart slowly, but you the decendant of the v13 dweller have been chosen by the village's elder to go out the wasteland explored by your ancestor to find the mighty G.E.C.K to fix all this hell happening.. and that is where your journey begins.

Now with some quick tips before you first time play this game:

I reccomend reading this guide to help you get started playing, trust me its worth to read than being torn to shreds by a small Enclave patrol or getting shotgunned in the face when you try to fight with melee in a random encounter. small spoilers because the guide also brings up the details with all the quests available in this game
http://fallout.wikia.com/wiki/The_Nearly_Ultimate_Fallout_2_Guide#Character_design

Don't ragequit over getting wrecked by a bunch of geckos or radscorpians, the more you play the game, the better.


Okay so now onto the Gameplay, its very Turnbased but its rewarding seeing the animations of someones torso being blown to bits by shotguns and mini-guns, even melting him like a witch with a plasma gun is entertaining too, of course you can also be blown to bits by anyone. there isn't open world exploration like you get in fallout 3 because outside of towns/other places will bring a large map with a green dot (you) click around and you move around, when you want to travel to another location for the side/main quests  you will often have random encounters such as radscorps, walking into a middle of a firefight between caravans and bandits, there are peaceful encounters like the caravans who will trade with you for caps (aka money) of course the small downside with trading is your karma status effects the caravans, some of them will refuse to trade with you either becuase you are known as a evil fat ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• villlain  or a goodie white knight of the wasteland it mainly depends on  locations that you are nearby like the cities, small hint there are easter egg encounters too!

You can also choose to do what ever you want. Killing before asking/chatting, turning the tables of the side quest (i.e giving the brahmin you were meant to guard to the twins when you trick your dumb tribal friend into running away)
you can't slaughter the villagers in your home cus otherwise the game will be over insta.

There are also Companions that you can take with you on your travels, based on my experience I will give you the details of the companions I had with me.

Vic This man may be your second/first companion you can bring along, he's good for ranged weapons, be sure to collect his rifle at his shack in the first town you go to, but he's often slow and bad for melee combat.

Lenny A ghoul, he's not great with combat and carrys a knife with him but he is a decent doctor, have him as your field medic and sort. Also he cannot run.

Marcus this guy has a talking head voice acted too, but if you want this big hulk with you, its best you either take his mini-gun away and give him a plasma rifle, or have him as your only companion because he will freaking kill every single thing in his line of fire no matter who's infront when you're in combat, his mini-gun often has a unaccurate shot hitting mutiple targets in a burst of fire which means he can instantly kill you or his fellow companion by accident.

K9 this cyber dog is simliar to the famous dog-meat but he can talk and is cool, you can find him inside a lab at the navvarro Enclave base, its best you get in there with the highwayman car otherwise you will have a pain in the ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• experience getting killed by enclave patrols in 1 turn every time.

Goris this DEATHCLAW is quite a badass, except he can only fight with his claws in melee so he can sometimes get in your line of fire including marcus's and his animation with his jedi cloak gets repeative.

The story also has multiple endings on every town and faction you have met along in your travels, your actions towards them will bring them a future, for example if you slaughter the slavers at the Den and free the slaves, the town will flourish and sort, and if you screw up modac its gonna die because you made a mistake on your decision.

Immersion on this game regardless of the graphics is really great too, you're gonna get tempted to kill somebody because of what-he-said about those poor ghouls or maybe even insulting you. This is not some fallout 3 where enclaves gets killed by revolvers, or deathclaws getting killed in 3 seconds or children being immune to gunshots Oh yeah you can kill kids in this game if you're a heartless monster :3  this is fallout 2 friend.


-fun turnbased gameplay
-immersive storyline
-able to do what you want that can effect karma or faction/town reputation including the ending of the faction and town.

reviewText:
The second post-apocalyptic classic.

As you may have already noticed from the screenshots, Fallout 2 is very similar to its predecessor. Not only in terms of the interface, gameplay or graphics, but also the story itself. Kind of.

Once you create your character with whatever abilities and skills you decide, you will enter the wasteland once again as a person from Arroyo, a village that has been started about 80 years ago by the Vault Dweller, the main character of the original Fallout.

Your main goal is to find a very important item that could save your people who are sick and diseased, and it's up to you how you cope with that quest. And if you decide to accept your fate and indeed go on this quest to find not only the item that's needed, but also the truth about many things you have wondered about, then prepare for one heck of a ride.

I, personally, have enjoyed the first game a bit more, but the atmosphere is still there and if you liked the original, you're going to like this as well. Definitely.

reviewText:
(In addition, I have hundreds of hours on the original retail version)

Where to begin?  This is one of my all-time favorite games, and I grew up with it along with the first game. It was part of my childhood and continues to be a part of my life all these years later, and it will always have a place in my heart.  Fallout 2 is excellent and anyone who likes RPGs who aren't afraid to play a game that isn't entirely welcoming should give it a shot; I admit I am somewhat biased because of my nostalgia but that doesn't explain the entirety of why I think this is an excellent game.  There is *much* more to this game than the references, humor and fourth wall breaking; that being said, the humor is a nice touch depending on your tastes.  This game deserves as much attention and recognition as the first in the series and I consider both games to be one in the same and part of the same collective experience.

This is game is punishing in certain ways, and is not that casual of an experience; and in some ways I would admit that this game isn't the most welcoming, but once you figure things out and start to progress there are numerous different possibilities and choices laid out before you, and you can play any type of character you choose and have any type of temperament you choose in this game world, which is rich and unique.

Fallout 1 and 2 haven't aged very well, although personally I can transcend that completely due to my nostalgia and attachment to the series; the game looks better now since we can change the screen resolution, and the game is even better with the Restoration Project mod.

You are the grandchild of the Vault Dweller from Fallout 1, the game takes place 80 years after the first game, and you are part of a primitive tribe which your ancestor founded.  You must save your tribe by finding the holy GECK.  Along the way in your quest, you can do many interesting things and talk to many interesting characters.

The gameplay is the same as in Fallout 1, which in my opinion, is a good thing. Fallout 2 is much longer and there is much more to do and see in Fallout 2 than the first (especially with the Restoration Project mod), although the first game is excellent for many of the same reasons this game is excellent.  Most people who enjoyed Fallout 1 (or similar titles) will probably enjoy this immensely also.  I would even recommend this game to people who don't normally play games like it, but are merely very interested in the Fallout lore.

There is an issue I have with the game but only due to playing it on newer, larger displays and playing it on a higher resolution than the game was initially intended for; certain scenes will look wrong if the resolution is set high.

In conclusion, this isn't for everyone and not everyone will be able to enjoy it in the same capacity as others might, for whatever reasons, whether it has to do with the age of the game or not.  But this is classic Fallout and deserves as much love as the first in the series.  This game is highly recommended for any fan of oldschool turn-based RPGs, this and its predecessor helped to redefine the genre. This game is old, but it's excellent and one of the best RPGs I've played, and is very well written.

I'd also highly recommend the Restoration Project mod, which includes the Unofficial Patch.  It restores new content into the game that the developers intended to have in the first place but weren't able to, and  you can choose which options you would like to install easily. killap.net

reviewText:
I loved videogames as a kid and my favorites were the action and rpg games where I played the hero with the sword slaying my enemies.  Naturally I was pumped as I put my max strength character into this world, heroically exterminating giant ants with my spear.  And after that earned me the title of 'Chosen One' nothing could stop me.

So weapon in hand I search for injustice in the closest town and find a slavers guild.  There is no room for this evil in my world!  I charge right through the front door and skewer the boss twice with my trusty spear of justice...   at which point six heavily armored guards blast my head and arms off with submachine guns, as my 11 year old eyes stare in shock at my blood sputtering corpse on the floor.

I would forever remember this day as when I TRULY understood why guns are better than swords.


Fallout 1 and 2 are both artifacts from a time when there was no mainstream gaming.  Big companies all made indie games, and this is a result when that money isn't restricted by demographics and overprotective mother influenced censorship.  No indie game can match the beauty that comes from collaboration and detail this game has in both its gameplay and art.

For truly shocking me into the reality of a world that no HD game has done since, Fallout 2 gets 10/10.

reviewText:
A Better RPG than Fallout 4Bleeding from several wounds, I thrust my spear once more toward my enemy, this time connecting, finally. I'm poisoned, bleary eyed and have six hitpoints remaining.
I just survived the first dungeon with a charismatic character. I killed some Giant Ants.

This is what Fallout was. A sprawling, tough RPG that actually required some amount of planning toward your character and your decisions. Even to this day the dialogue is great and the story gripping yet allows a sense of freedom. If you want a fighting character you better make a fighting character. When I played Fallout 4 I made an incredibly charismatic, intelligent character with poor stats in fighting. I still managed to kill everything. In Fallout 2 I barely survived the first dungeon, getting mauled by Lesser Scorpions and Giant Ants, all because I wanted my character to be a talker, not a fighter.
Obviously it's aged; three mousepointers need to be alternated between; combat, movement and interaction. There's a panel that brings up skills and not everything is made immediately clear.
But if those main 'problems' with the game don't scare you away then this is a great game. It's worth a try, even if just to see how Fallout was and to experience a true gaming classic; one that will remain for countless years as a great game in the history of gaming.

reviewText:
Hoo boy. I have mixed feelings on this one.

Fallout 2 is more or less the same as Fallout in terms of gameplay, but with improvements, which is certainly a plus. There is one minor gameplay quibble I have, and that's that they slightly nerfed the Turbo Plasma Rifle for no good reason. Why, besides trying to make the Pulse Rifle seem better by comparison? That seems like the completely wrong way to go about it, making and trying to balance new content by changing the old. It was fine! On the subject of equipment changes, they also reduced the weight of the Power Armor by about half with no explanation. I'd accept that if you at least acknowledged it, but now it just seems kind of silly. Just one offhand remark about removing unnecessary systems in there! THAT'S IT!

Anyway, the story issue is a bit more complex. The focus in Fallout 2, I've noticed, is more based on the moment-to-moment or area-to-area experience, rather than Fallout 1's cohesive whole. As a result, the whole thing seems more scattered, muddier, and overall less entertaining and less absorbing, as they'll do anything to make sure that you're never not entertained, while Fallout made sure that there was a single, easy-to-follow narrative, leading to a better and more consistent atmosphere.

One other really annoying thing: the game takes forever to get going, especially for gun-oriented characters. The Temple of Trials and the majority of Klamath have nothing but scorn for your desire to find a single ranged weapon that doesn't have a 1-bullet clip, and even then you're still on shaky ground until maybe the Den. For a while, I even tried to just play a hand-to-hand character for this game simply because the beginning is so stupidly unhelpful! In contrast, take a look at Fallout 1's beginning. You're kicked out the door. You have a gun, a knife, and ammo to spare (and a definite and straightforward goal). Boom. All playstyles are go. Even with the gameplay sorting itself out, the whole Fallout 2 package doesn't really get engaging until Gecko. After that, though, it really does pick up steam, and by the Enclave you realize that just now you're getting the experience and thrills that Fallout 1 was delivering from square one. (I should probably mention that eventually I was so desperate for some fun way forward that I looked up Per Jorner's excellent guide. That was what truly rekindled my interest, and I urge everyone to check it out. It contains levels of love and research of and for a game that I haven't seen since Everything You Wanted to Know About Headcrabs and More. Check that out too, actually.)

Overall, I like Fallout 1 more. Fallout 2 is huge, much bigger than its predecessor, and has its share of wonderous delights (don't get me wrong on that), but more often than not for me they're hidden behind some sort of obtuse non-engaging..sloppiness? Design oversight? Overreaching? that the first game rarely if ever had. I guess I'd still recommend it -mostly for the story connectivity- but really, Fallout 1 is the better of the two, in my opinion.

TL;DR I like Fallout 1 more, it seems to me that they got sloppy with this one. Too big to ignore, though.

Also, some of the canonical and best endings are hidden behind lazy bugs? WHAT?

EDIT: Just recently, I've been replaying the Fallout games in preparation for Fallout 2. When it came time for Fallout 2, I used Per Jorner's guide to speedrun through the thing in the course of a night. Playing through the entire thing once was enough for me.

reviewText: Few games today can compare to the impact that the Fallout Series has left in the minds of gamers, young and old. Differing from the third installment (not including Fallout Tactics, Fallout BoS, or any of the other spinoffs that are not considered part of the Fallout lore canon) in the series, the first and second installments were more so based around strategy, smart thinking, constant saves, and knowing when to either fight or run. Compared to the more recent installments, this game, along with the prequel, is somewhat like playing a game of chess. Knowing when to move, when to strike, and when to regret poor decisions. Not a game for those who are not good with tactics. Sadly, it starts somewhat slowly, and once you get really going later on in the game, it get's to the point where not even the more deadly mobs, like Deathclaws or Wamaningos, can not do much harm to you or your party due to how strong someone can become in the game. Let's talk about the story. You, the Player Character, are the son or daughter of the original Vault Dweller, the main protaginist of the first Fallout game. At the start, you go out to find the Garden of Eden Creation Kit, or more simply known as the G.E.C.K, in order to prevent your village of Arroyo from dying of famine and disease. As time goes on, it goes from trying to prevent your crops from dying, to trying to save your village from the Enclave, the remnants of the American Government, who captured your fellow villagers to perform experiments on them, and you're the only one who can do anything about it. Well, you and your party of not-so-merry pals. Ranging from a Artificial Intelligence, to a super mutant, to even a intelligent Deathclaw, you have a wide variety of followers to recruit. Personally, I give this game a 9 / 10, a great strategic game with a decent story and and a lot of replayability, I highly recommend this to anyone who likes the Fallout series, as well as anyone who likes to think strategicly.

reviewText:
In The End, Why Not Just Hit Children In The Groin With A Sledgehammer - An Official Waffle King Review
~Find more here.[www.nonm.co.uk]


In the event that the world ever ends, be it zombie apocalypse, nuclear armageddon, or any other fun kind of catastrophe, I feel like humanity definitely will live on. We're a stubborn race of beings. Like cockroaches. We're everywhere, we just won't go away, and we seem to find a way to procreate everywhere.

Out of every possible way that the human race could near extinction, I think being mostly annihilated by an atomic bomb or so would be the best way to go. Especially if Fallout is something we could go on.


In Fallout 2 specifically, one of the great tactical CRPG classics, an atomic post-apocalyptic wasteland is a pretty fun place. You can pretty much do whatever you want.


Fallout 2 takes place after the events of Fallout 1, with your character from the first game starting their own village outside the Vault to live out the rest of their days. Your new character is a descendant of them, and has grown up outside the Vault. Their village has had a horrible drought, and it's up to you as The Chosen One to set off and save the world.


Fallout 2 is near identical to the first game in terms of gameplay, polished and upgraded to make it the definitive classic Fallout experience. If you're looking for the very best in terms of isometric, tactical CRPG action, Fallout 2 is probably your game.


The time limit is gone. You're free to explore Fallout 2's vast, open world to your heart's content. There's all sorts of side-quests, missions, and just random nonsense to get yourself into. You can join the mafia, become a pornstar, or just slaughter every human being you see. It's all free game.


To start, you just need to create your character. There is a selection of pre-made ones, but the real fun of the game is creating your own character to fully immerse yourself in the world of Fallout.


From there, you just need to play through what could be called a crude tutorial dungeon. After that, the world opens up. Slowly at first, as your stats will not allow much exploration when the wasteland is crawling with giant scorpions and freaks. But with time, you'll be able to do as you please.


Mechanically, it's better than the original Fallout. It plays better, it controls better, and it has more depth than the original in terms of what the world offers. The gameplay has been balanced to make all character skills viable, which was an issue with the first Fallout game. As a sequel, it definitely has at least improved upon the original.


However, I personally still prefer the first one. Fallout 2, I felt took a lot of what made Fallout special out of the equation. The time limit, while brutal, was part of giving that sensation of hopelessness and urgency. And having your character born outside of a Vault, it took some of the impact away of having stepped out into the wasteland for the first time.


The story was not as compelling, and it didn't really feel like Fallout at first to me. The early game is particularly slow, and it takes a while to really capture that Fallout vibe.


As an older game, it is still a little bit dated. Especially in the graphics department. But still completely enjoyable as a game. I always did have a thing for older games. I like them a little mature, you know?


Regardless, Fallout 2 is still a very special game. There aren't very many other games where you can blow up small children with powerful explosives, become a slaver, or have sex with a mutant. Fallout 2 really is something special, and it's an essential part of any PC game collection. The sheer depth of the game constantly gives off the feeling that there's still more to do and more to see.


In the event of a real nuclear apocalypse, I call dibs on leader of the pornstar mafia. No, I already got dibs, it's official. Too bad. You can be something else.


I called it, it's mine.

reviewText:
Gr8 gmae m80s.

Pros:
-Goofy. Very goofy, sometimes.
-Good variety of weapons
-Most companions are useful (Vic is the most useful, with is gr8 repair.)
-Restoration project (Add's SO many bug fixes, cut content, etc into the game the dev's took out, such as the childkiller perk picture was turned back into that fallout guy kicking a pregnant woman in the gut. )
-Good story
-Many references to the predecessor, or other games in the series. (It's a personal thing. I like when a game does this.)
-Some of the puns are actually entertaining to read.
-SEVERAL hours of gameplay (Even after you finish the game. You can still do many,many things.) I've spent 100+ hours on one character.
-Good graphics (Although not the most important thing in the game by a longshot, they are still great for 1998.)
-Mod support
-Virtually no bugs (I've only seen one through 3 playthroughs)
-You almost never need to scavange for ammo, unless you are almost completely out. Most vendors in the game sell at least some ammo of some type. (i.e, 10mm ammo)
-Karma can very much effect your game.
-Being a childkiller actually has precautions, other than alot of people hating you. Bounty hunters will come after you. What they have depends on your level. They can have leather jackets and 10mm pistols/Hunting Rifles (Level 3-8*) to guys in Enclave power armor with very powerful weapons like miniguns, gauss rifles, etc. (level 15+*) IF you kill them, its very good loot.
Pros/Cons (Problems, but easily fixed.):
-AP Ammo is useless without the Rest. Project (Rest. Project is very easy to install, just download, choose custom install, and find Yet Another Ammo Mod. Check that, and finish the rest of the things. AP ammo is very useful against decently armored oponents now.)
-Companions can constantly kill you with machine guns. Stay out of their way. (Amazing example is Marcus with a Bozar or Minigun. Very annoying. Just give him a laser, plasma, etc rifle if you can spare the ammo and gun itself.)
-Don't make Sulik charge at people. He will just get himself killed, pretty much instantly. Make him stay near you and give him a .223 Pistol (If possible.) It has the same sprite as an SMG, so he can use it. .223 ammo is very common.
-Untill you get to Klamath, the beginning of the game is somewhat boring.
-LIke stated before, there are bugs, but most are rare.
Cons:
- The few bugs there are, some are kinda bad (i.e crashes the game.)
- Enemy burst fire does a bit too much damage sometimes. (I was wearing Advanced Power Armor Mk2, and a raider burst fired a CAWS, it was a crit, and it did 83 damage. Raider pls, that's bullsheit)

reviewText:
Fallout 2 is a very intresting classic game in the Fallout series. Here is the list of pros and cons.
Pros
*gore I love the pixilated gore
*unique custimisation system
*nice combat system
*many more choseable allies than the first Fallout
*great story that follows up well on the first fallout
Cons
* No mini map
* Some skills are redundant and rarely utilised
* Your allies can die permenantly and since there is a select few number of allies you are going to have to redo battles over and over to get a result where non of your allies die
*  weapon iniquality: guns are better than mellee weapons, although this is realistic I would have hoped rpgs wouldn't stoop to such realism
* and last of all the frequent much dreaded MISS
Overall though it is pretty fun to play this 1998 classic.

reviewText:

reviewText: This is one of my favorite games of all time. It is very old but that does not take away anything from it. The begining of the game is extreamly bad. The first temple will make you want to stop playign but after that its amazing. As you progress in the story you go to different cites with 10 or so different side quests. And they are very interesting. One is about a ghost where you help her find peace. Another is where you go to a bar on one side of town where drinks are twice as much as a bar on the other side of town and you can do a quest where you go snooping around looking for the reason those drinks are so low. In the begining of the game you won't have much and combat can be a little difficult since in fast travel it brings you to a map where you click around in the direction the NPC's told you the next city is which is very unique and interesting. Although sometimes you will run into a group of bandits ir wild animals trying to kill you and since there are edges of the land that you are on you can just run away very easily. Over all this is a great game.

A post-apocalyptic turn-based RPG like no other.

This game is a classic. I've put in hundreds of hours in it playing different ways with different characters before I added it to my steam library (I own the discs for 1 and 2).

Fallout has some of the most memorable designs and lore of any post-apocalyptic setting I've seen, and I would definitely recommend it for anyone who enjoys a good turn-based, isometric RPG romp.

reviewText:
One of my favorite RPGs and games in general.

Sequel to the first post-nuclear simulator, Fallout 2 retained the same good qualities of the first Fallout with an experience just as good. Fallout 2 doesn't change too much in comparison to its predecessor in terms of the actual gameplay mechanics, but the the improvements and more content, like improved companions and a larger game world, are a welcome that offers plenty of replay value. The charm of Fallout 2 is the change in the nature from the first. The wasteland has progressed greatly in the last 80 years since the events of Fallout, and it offers a much different atmosphere. Trees are starting to grow back again, settlements as large as cities rebuild, governments forming, civilization is getting back on its feet. And with that comes a constant struggle for power across the waste among these different factions. And throughout the game the fate of these factions depend on your actions. The world feels more alive and its a welcome change to see how the universe has progressed since the Vault Dweller walked the wasteland.

Along side these changes to the atmosphere comes a much different approach to the game. It's seemingly more satirical with many pop culture references and breaking of the fourth wall. It's different from what you'd expect from Fallout but its can be humorous enough to get a chuckle out of it when you get the references.

However, there is one major flaw with this game and it's the bugs; and there are a lot. What I would say is the biggest issue with the bugs are with the quest. Many of the quest in the game are heavily bugged, even to the point that it can completely block off an entirely different path to completing a quest which is rather disappointing because you'll have to settle for a lesser outcome rather than the one you desired. It's a real shame too because Black Isle Studios did some outstanding work with quest design, but the experience is held back by the nasty bugs. Despite these issues, I am still able to forgive the game for the rest of the great work put into it.

In the end, it's the Fallout you've always loved but with the added joy of getting addicted to Jet, becoming a pornstar, or punching children with a mega powerfist because they thought it was a good idea to steal from the Chosen One. And then later you'll be labeled as 'Child Killer'.

reviewText:
Fallout 2: A Post Nuclear Role Playing Game is a role-playing open world game featuring a considerably larger map/world and a far more extensive storyline, than those of Fallout 1.

It is hands down one of the best games I've ever played (and that says a lot about it). The fact that the game was made in 1998 makes it even more impressive.

Fallout 2 centres around the protagonist a.k.a. 'The Chosen One' and is entasked with the duty by the elder of his village to find and retrieve the Garden Eden Creation Kit (G.E.C.K.) which is a device that can create thriving communities out of the post-apocalyptic wasteland.

The game comprises of exploring and travelling in the open world as well as speech and quests to various characters and NPC. In addition to the role playing elements, a unique turn-based shooter is used during combat. This incredible blend  makes the game so widely stimulating and intense. It is an experience unlike one other. Not to mention the storyline is as engaging as it is compelling.

The player's actions throughout the game dictate what future story or gameplay opportunities are available. A player can choose to inhibit/aid certain NPCs and affects the entire gameplay. Aside from combat, speech also plays a huge role in the final outcome of the game.

Before the game begins, the player is allowed to create his/her character with a variety of different skill, perk, trait and character point (S.P.E.C.I.A.L) builds. Because of the extensive outcome and scenarios, Fallout 2 is a game with incredibly high replay value.

There is not much else to say, this game is IN-F***ING-CREDIBLE!
GET IT (if you haven't already)

6*/5 - 110% would recommend

reviewText:
Fallout 2, like it's predecessor and sequels, stands to date as one of the greatest roleplaying games ever devised. First introduced to the original game in the series as a youth, I quickly became addicted to both the setting and the story being told; I loved the choices you were asked to make, and the customisation options that were available to you; I adored the pre-war 50s feel that inhabited the wasteland, even as you carried plasma rifles and power armour into battle.

In a word, Fallout 2, like the other games in the series, is sublime. As a fan of roleplaying games in general, I recognise that the post-apocalyptic genre is harder than others to make enticing - and yet Fallout somehow manages to nail it. Gore and mature themes meet head on with quirky humour, memorable locations and characters (Dogmeat and Harold the Ghoul being just two), and an expansive world to explore.

Unlike the first game in the series, Fallout 2 has you taking on the role of a tribal youth who is sent out into the wasteland in order to secure a G.E.C.K. - a Garden of Eden Creation Kit - which will help your primitive people make the land furtile and liveable again. Who your character is - what gender, what they're good at, what their quirks are - is entirely up to you, as are the dialogue and moral decisions you make, and the route you take across the wasteland. With side quests all over the place, you can spend hours after hours trudging through the Fallout world, making your mark as either a sentinel of justice, or a madman with a shotgun. Good or evil, hero or villian - it's entirely up to you.

The latter games might be controversial to a select few - after all, not everyone liked Bethesda's treatment of a classic game, and it's their perogative to think that way. However, it's almost unanimous fact that Fallout 2, like it's predecessor, stands as one of the greatest RPGs ever made.

Buy this game.

The world is alive and connected. You can play in any way you want. Your moral compass can point in any direction. I still find new things even after all these years.

reviewText: If your a Fallout die hard that means you have owned this game and perhaps several copies. I know I have owned three copies in the jewel case alone, plus I now own it on Steam because I purchased the Anthology. Praises to steam for bringing this game back with all the fixes. And if you want to run this game for more fun, please Install Killaps Restoration Patch and really enjoy Fallout 2 the way it was meant to be played.\n\nThe writing for this game is above the standard and while Fallout never got the vast expansions say Baldur's Gate or Icewind Dale got, this game is a gem. If you appreciate the isometric system, this is the game for you. For those who only played Fallout 3, New Vegas and and Fallout 4; I would challenge you to go back to the roots. Play both Fallout 1 and Fallout 2.

reviewText: Fallout 2 is a great game, and perhaps one of the best in the Fallout series. The setting, characters, and music are all wonderful. However, the combat is very dated and the game is infested with bugs. Certain quests and outcomes are simply unobtainable. In addition, I was annoyed that for a game that features many different solutions to complete a task, the game would often force you into doing things during crucial moments that if you had not previously focused upon, would be very difficult to do. Still, I can overlook this and say it is a game that any western rpg player should try out.

reviewText:
Best. Game. Ever.

Nostalgia! The feelings! I have finished the game several times, finding something new each and every playthrough when I was a kid. The best part is that when the Internet came, I have googled for a playthhrough description and still found a couple of new unknown things to do in this game, that's how thought through it is, that is how much effort have been put in it. It's a masterpeace of gaming. It's a legend! It's Fallout!

Even at the time it was released, the graphics were considered a downside of this game. Half-Life was released about that time with much better 3D graphics.The lack of graphics makes this game trick your brain into turning it's imagination center on or whatever it is called. It's like a book, makes you dream while you are awake, imagine how the caracters and places would look like in real life, placing you directly into the wasteland. That is why Fallout 3 and New Vegas will never be better than this to me, they look not as I have imagined it to be as a kid.

The music is on point! The sounds, the instruments used add to the atmosphere of the place. The first second you are in New Reno you understand that mobsters and gangsters rule the place. Or Gecko? In Gecko you feel the place is dead even is ghouls are walking and talking and ready to beat your ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• after they caught you stealing. Still, the music tells you life abandoned this place long ago. To this day I can tell by heart which melody plays in which place of the map.

Dialogues... Just call Enclave from teminal in Gecko and you will understand that dialogues are the heart of this game. The can be very serious and almost existential, they can be simple and super fun. Basically, 50% of the time playing this game you are sitting and reading through millions of lines of dialogue. The other half you are looting, kicking ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•, levelling up your character, buying and selling stuff, picking locks. But the majority of time you are carefully reading not to miss a clue on a quest or simply cause it is interesting.

Combination of this three things made a perfect game for me. As this review starts, this is the best game ever for me and I do not think this will ever change.

Still playing this from time to time. Damn this game is good.

On the downside - I feel really old. Ancient. I work with people who are younger than this game, that is how ancient I am.

P.S. I know that nobody will read this review. I pay my respect to this game this way.

reviewText: A much desired improvement on gameplay from the first one. Tons to do, easy to get lost. One of the major problems with the game is the first 5 levels. You will get mercilessly murdered at even the daintiest of encounters. You will need to do all of the meanial tasks in the first two towns, possibly skipping most of the inital radscorpians. Once past there you will find a delightful jewel though. The combat has been tweaked, you no longer wait for the illogical math models of the first, though this one suffers on occasion from terrible hit percentage calculations. The NPC's are not as deep I felt as the original, but there are so many more to talk to that the trade off was worth it. The intolerance of ghoul and super mutants is emphasized, as well as some of the other less than noble human characteristics. They need to bring the Highwayman back.

reviewText: Fallout 2 is the pinnacle of the Fallout experience (in my opinion). This game presents a truly open world with hundreds of choices for any style of character to truly live in. Besides a slow start, increase in comic references, more complex story, and a few bugs here and there; Fallout 2 truly exceeds the accomplishments of its first installment here. Although most prefer the 3D titles in the Fallout series, this one truly feels the most imaginative and true to style in the series. If you haven't played it and are inclined to play 2D isometric RPG‚Äôs, this one is a real treat.

reviewText:
I will start with saying that this game is far better then Fallout 3 (ps3), Fallout 4 (pc) and i probably enjoyed it more then new Vegas (ps3) too and tactics ( only played 2 hrs).

Onto the review.
Gameplay: This game is a turn based rpg , set in a post apoclyptic world. You have huge map to explorer and you can if you want to go straight to the last locations. The game has tons of various cool character you can talk to. And quests you can do. With multiple factions all with they own agendas, and if you don`t like any of them you can either kill them or skip doing those quests all together.  Also every companion can be order to be offensive, use melee weapons or ranged, carry stuff or to wait or move if they stand in you way , witch may happens sometimes. It might no be the best gameplay but it still works just fine. And the game is neither to hard nor to unforgiving.

Character development / leveling/skills and quest: How your develop you character is entirely up to you. Do you want to fist you way trough the game you can do that.  Do you wanna be a sniper and let your companions if you want to have companions do the fight for you , you can do just that. Do you want to play the game alone you can do that. For every four level you reach you can choose a skill and some of this skills is pretty good and actually has a meaning. Do you want to be a sweet talker and try to talk your way trough most of the quests you can do that. Compared to the later fallout especially fallout 4 at least in a large extent you have more freedom in how you do your quests and how you accomplish them all with multiple solutions and your choices also has  consequences. All the character you meet have their own personalities and perhaps even problems or a reason they need your help or a reason  why the want to join you and lastly those character especially on the companion side is plentiful and enough of them but not to many and neither to few. All skills have they own usefulness. Almost every character you meet has something to tell about the world. Plus if you really want to you can be a made - man/woman.  And lastly you earn exp by doing quests and killing or even picking up a special items or using seeing special encounters.  So yeah the game is pretty violent. Like shooting the groin of someone or the head of someone.

Factions: A short note on factions. Every factions as previously said have they own agendas. Some are evil som are good some are somewhere in between. Some want to make prostitution and gambling legal. Some want to focus on something else.

Setting: Perhaps most important of all is the setting. The setting is great. It feels very mush like an a post-apocalyptic game. All of the locations feel different in a good way. Different cultures. Different rules in the different places. Every places has it own mini-stories of side quests to tell. And with the wonderful music it could nt be any/much better. And the game has tons of Charm and Humor.

Music: the soundtrack is very good. And a lot of the tracks if not all you will remember.It really helps you immerse yourself into the setting

Bonus: I would put it here. The humor is very good. There is a lot of times you will laugh. Like missing a 95% hit or hitting a target with 20% hit for that matter.  You will laugh by the funny and witty and good written dialogue. A lot of cool Easter eggs that even i understood or laughed and thought was funny, i am not the best at finding Easter eggs, but i could in this game.
And the ending is more then good enough to and so is the voice acting at least for that time. And  despite some few crashes the game is still utterly fantascic. Give it a shot , even if you disliked fallout 3/4. Hugely different.

Score : highly recommended 10/10 if you enjoy turn based rpg set in a wonderful and brilliant rpg setting
One of the best pc game i have ever played if not the best . The only one that is close in Planescape, Deus ex and perhaps Max payne 2 and Portal 2.

And just if you wonder i would rate new Vegas 9.5

fallout 4 6-7/10

reviewText:
Set roughly 80 years after Fallout 1, the world once again needs the aid of an individual to overcome a great evil. Originally you're sent out from your tribe, founded by the original Vault Dweller from F1, to retrieve a GECK that will help them survive as their village is dying. Needless to say, a lot more than that is going on which you will uncover soon enough.

The world of Fallout 2 feels similliar to Fallout 1's (from here F1). The very south of F2's map is actually connected to F1's top, making it possible for the player to revisit a few of the old locations, such as Vault 13 and 15, as well as the NCR, which used to be Shady Sands. Other than that's there's a lot of new places to discover, including personal favorite of mine such as New Reno and a locationIreallycan'tnamewithoutspoilingthegame.

As for the combat and levelling mechanics, these are the same as in F1, meaning you start the game by picking your SPECIAL and tag skills and as you defeat enemies in turn based combat and levelling up, you get to spend more skill points on various skills. The use of AP for moves in combat is a really neat system.

As for F2 as a sequel, it's pretty great. The mechanics from F1 are re-used but other than that, it's a direct continuation on the lore with new events, a (mostly) new setting, all new story line and great characters.

The massive downside of Fallout 2, however, is the start. The game starts in an insanely ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• tutorial, and the first few hours are annoying as ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•. The SPECIAL you pick at the start wil also really influence the game a *ton*. I, for example, went with 4 strenght, leaving me unable to use 90% of the weapons untill much later on, which was a major ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• off. Amongst that the enemies suddenly go from easy to kill to pain in the ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•, and if you're not prepared for that you're having a hard time. A good companion team is basically a must at that point.


Before I wrap this up, I must say Fallout 2 has some absolutely hilarious moments to make up for some of the rage it might cause, such as the Caf√© of Broken Dreams, the Bridge Guardian, conversations with certain NPCs and...SERGEANT DORNAN.


Overall, 8.5/10.
