reviewText: Fallout 2, the successor to Fallout, a game that follows the apocalyptic aftermath of an alternate history where America, Asia and Europe have been subject to a nuclear resource war. In Fallout 2, the world is much larger and appropriately filled with interesting cities, towns, villages, and abandoned and occupied vaults. The story takes place after the actions of the Vault Dweller from Fallout, and many familiar faces will appear. There is, however, a new threat to the denizens of the wasteland. A powerful faction with advanced pre-war technology, who see the people of the irradiated wastes as monsters -- indistinguishable from ghouls and super mutants. Many new lively characters, stories, choices and weapons await in this great game.\n\n9/10

reviewText:
Fallout 2: A Post Nuclear Role Playing Game. I have many fond memories of this game, it is one of my all time favorites and even after all these years, after all the hours and hours and hours I have put into the game across several different computers; I can still play it shamelessly for hours and never get bored. Its like a great film that you never tire of. I bought Fallout 2 back in '99, as a teen and could not stop playing it. I ended up becoming so engrossed in the game, that I took to the internet and found myself at the No Mutants Allowed forums where I started a long running RP called Fallout: Systematic Annihilation (My name was TRAG on those boards.) The RP was a little hit on the website, and we had quite a few fans that read it regularly and even joined in the fun. But, I didn't stop there- Chris Avellone started releasing a little document called- The Fallout Bible. I was pulled in yet again. I have read that Bible more than once- I even have a digital copy on my cell phone for my reading pleasure. Yeah, this game started an obsession. Thankfully, it never got bad enough to where restraining orders were necessary (This is a joke of course, but there are those out there that have gone that far).
So, you have read how this game has touched my life, and inspired my imagination. Now, you are probably wondering- where is the review!?!
Fallout 2 is an isometric post apocalyptic role playing game with turn-based combat. That being said, this is not just any isometric RPG, this is one of the most well written, deep, open world rpgs ever crafted. Your choices here carry real weight within the world- Want to be a Slaver? A rough, hard living slave catcher/seller. All you have to do is get a tattoo on your forehead that the world can see and you can be one. The only problem is that people really do see it and their reactions to you will reflect that. Needless to say, Slavers aren't exactly welcome in many places in the wasteland. You may wish to rethink that life choice.
But, this game is not just about career choice, this is a game with a deep strategic combat system that will challenge even the most hardened RPG gamer. The game does not hold your hand and more than likely you will die a lot. Saving often is the best tool in your arsenal, and you will be relieved when you can reload your game only a few moments before you told that Super Mutant and his pals to shove it up his you know what, and instead he shoved it up yours...Lets move on.
This is a CRPG in every sense of the word, so if you get the feel that there is a feeling that you could be playing this on a table with some friends and a cashe of multicolored dice, you probably could. In fact- There is a Pen and Paper version of the S.P.E.C.I.A.L. system (the rules system the game is powered by.) on the internet and you can find it at No Mutants Allowed (the most well known Fallout fan site, find them here http://www.nma-fallout.com/ .)
There is so much that I can say about this game, but I won't, because I believe that you owe it to yourself to see it with your own eyes.
Fallout 2 is considered one of the greatest RPGs of all time for a reason: It lives up to the previous statement. It really is one of the greatest RPGs of all time. The writing is top notch, the sheer amount of choice and freedom. The methodical and satisfying development of your main character from an upstart, inexperienced tribal into a wasteland killing machine who is feared throughout the region, or a hero reveared by the struggling wasteland people. The choice is yours and your actions and decisions will determine the man/woman you become in this harsh and unforgiving post apocalyptic wasteland. You will need all the help you can get, and companions are there to meet and join your quest to restore your village and save its inhabitants from starvation, disease, and destruction.
This game is so detailed for its time, that even today I am finding things I have never seen in the game before; and I have been playing it since 1999, a year after it was released! If that doesn't give you an idea of the replayability factor I don't know what will.
If you purchase this game, you will come back to it year after year. And if you are a fan of pen and paper RPGS, CRPGS, or old school RPGs, then Fallout 2 is a godsend. Bigger and crazier than its predecessor Fallout (Which itself is an AMAZING game.) Fallout 2 takes you to the future that everyone hopes will never happen and lets you either wallow in it, or conquor it.
I HIGHLY recommend this game for any RPG fan. It will ensnare you, it will inspire you!!

reviewText:
+ amazingly interesting quests
+ great RPG system, perks
+ unforgettable soundtrack
+ dark, yet humorous
+ funny and believable dialogues
+ incredible atmosphere
+ challenging to beat; not overly hard though
+ runs perfecty on modern systems after one fan-made patch
- doesn't run perfectly on modern systems without the fan-made patch

The ultimate post-nuclear experience. Forget the F3/NV; Fallout 1 (and Fallout 2) is how the post-apocalyptic world could actually look like.

Harshness, seriousness and darkness of the post-apocalyptic world? It's in it.
Humour, hyperbole, light tone and pop-culture references? It's in there, without diminishing the serious tone of the game.

INCREDIBLE dialogues and your possibilities in it. Great music, fits the atmosphere perfectly. Decent storyline. The number of possibilities on how you could play through this game is uncountable. You can beat this game in 9 minutes 17 seconds (literally, speedrun is on youtube somewhere) or in average 20 hours without getting bored for 1 second. For me it's possibly the best RPG out there.

New Fallouts were decent games but sh*t-tier Fallouts. You want to know why is Fallout considered one of the best RPG series ever? Play this (or Fallout 2) and forget the sequels for now.

(While it helps, you don't have to play Fallout 1 to fully enjoy this (I've played this one first btw), there are only few relations to Fallout 1 in the F2 story, it's completely independent)

reviewText: Fallout 2 - Fallout 2 is a direct sequel to Fallout 1; with only a year in between releases, not much has changed. The interface is fixed now, so it‚Äôs more in line with modern standards, but the combat is still freaking slow, so if you happen to choose non-combat skillsets, you are screwed. The graphic is improved which is pretty impressive given how little development time Interplay has between Fallout 1 and Fallout 2. As a result, innovation wasn‚Äôt present in this game at all. Players from Fallout 1 will notice a crap ton of game-breaking glitches being fixed in Fallout 2, you won‚Äôt get boxed in by friendly NPCs anymore because you can just push them away. The world is big(ger), and the plot is interesting as usual. Fair warning though, the game introduction is epically slow. Play Fallout 1 first, depending on how much you love that should help you determine if Fallout 2 is worth your time.

reviewText:
Fallout 2 Review
Is it still great all these years down the line?
Pros:
Solid gameplay
Wider variety of weapons over Fallout 1
More locations than Fallout 1
LOTS more companions
More intresting characters
Talking Heads
Active modding community (mods still being made at the time of writing)
You can have a robo-dog
You can team-up with a... Well, you'll know once you get to it. Wouldn't want to spoil a nice suprise :)
Loads of content

Cons
There's a bit of stuff I consider uneccessary. New Reno as a whole is... Well really designed for fan service. There's a brothel and a porn studio here.
When you have entire PERKS centered around sex, you know something is wrong.
Progression in the beginning is slow
Geckos. Screw these things. Especially at the start.
Missing content that's easily replaced with Fallout 2 Restoration mods.
Getting a gun that isn't a pea shooter takes FOREVER. Prices are INSANELY high after Fallout 1. I mean, REALLY high. At the start, it cost me my entire supply of money, a gun I previously had (which was an EVEN WORSE pea shooter) and whatever I could scrounge up from the houses near by to get a 10MM pistol. Still a pea shooter, but it dealt more damage.
Random encounters are FAR too frequent. It's frustrating when the second you leave the city you're attacked by tweleve dogs, and it takes a few minutes for them to end their turn. And you can't run because they've trapped you.
Relies too heavily on pop-culture refrences that are now outdated. Funny at the time, but in 2015, some don't make sense or some are just plain stupid.

On the whole, Fallout 2 is a game everyone who can think should own. This isn't a game for people that played 3 and New Vegas and enjoyed the shooter aspects: This is a bare knuckle, hard core RPG, and you WILL die. Many many times.

reviewText:
(Note: Bought this game elsewhere, but wanted a digital version)

The sequal to the fantastic Fallout game, you know you are in good hands. This game is set years after the first where you play as a decendent of the Vault Dweller who has been tasked to go out and find the vault for it may contain a G.E.C.K (Garden of Eden Creation Kit) which could save your people as many are sick and dying as are there Brahman. You start by proving your worth by entering the temple of the vault dweller and retriving the vault 13 suit left by your ancestor before heading out for the elusive Vault 13.

This game is far better than the previous by doing away with the timer that was in the first one, however the start does involve you running into giant ants and lesser radscorpions in the temple and being armed with only a spear so if you focus on gunpower, there's a good chance you might die or be unable to get through the temple. This game also has the introduction to power gloves if you wish to make a mellee focused character where no previous such weapon exsisted in the first and you were stuck otherwise. There is more adult subject matter as you get to sleep with numerous women (or men depending on sex or your choice) with only a brief description which is somehow more graphic than the Bethesda attempt (dissapointing since the game is a 18, you'd think you'd be treated as a adult) but that's a different discussion for something else.

For those who have played Fallout 3, this game is where the Enclave first appeared and in this you run into references to the previous game (appearance of Harold, a discovery of a horde of water chips and a Super mutant who is worried about getting a woman pregnant) as well as an evolution in the society where no longer do people collect bottle caps, but crudly made discs called Dollars.  Ghouls and Super Mutants are no longer a big enemy as they have been trying to intergrate with society (except for Vault City which is Xenophobic) and even gain a Super Mutant as a companion as well as many other interesting and even hidden companions.

Well worth if you enjoyed the first game and a lot of fun if you like RPGs in general. You don't need to have played the first one as you can always ask questions about why the world is the way it is and the story has a totally different enemy than the last one. You also have multiple possible endings when you complete the game like the previous one and get to see how Shady Sands has evolved into the infamous NCR.

reviewText: The controls aren't initially too bad, especially when you finally master them. Unfortunately, Black Isle Studios didn't have the knack to implement an abundance of voice actors. Truth be told there are only a handful of them in the entire game. Everything else is good old fashion dialogue. Sure, you might here me and other people complain about this. But let's just say, for the shake of this review. I get over the fact the game only has a limited amount of voice actors until Fallout 3. The only major problem I've encountered thus far with Fallout 1 through 2 (including Fallout Tactics) is the despicable combat system. I mean this combat system sucks.. I'm talking atari style combat.. A friendly individual fires first, then a hostile target fires second. It essentially goes back and fourth until one or the other is dead. This is extremely unrealistic, and truthfully. I don't believe there was any excuse for this whatsoever. Take my word for it, I'm a huge fan of the Fallout series; but this is just ridiculous. In closing this message, I want to add the story is of course outstanding. I hope one day they'll consider doing a remastered version of both Fallout 1 and Fallout 2. Preferably with Fallout 4's new creation engine.

reviewText:
I played this game when it first came out.  I thought it was awsome, and in its time, it was.

However, times change.  After playing it a bit, I have found that I do not have patience for old-school game mechanics.
For example: You get a quest to Find X.  X can be a person, or an object.  And that is all you get.  Please find X and get something from him.  You would think getting the object from Mr. X would be the problem and perhaps you are right.  However, you must spend HOURS clicking on everyone in town to find Mr. X, IF HE IS EVEN IN THAT SAME town.  If it is an object, lets hope you notice it amonge the muddled brown textures sitting on the ground somewhere.

Do you want to recall what NPC said about something, perhaps there is a hint in something he or she said?  You will not find any such notes in your trusty pip boy.  Perhaps you can find the NPC and talk to them again.  Maybe they will go through thier dialog again, or perhaps they will just ask you if you got the job done yet and you will be SOL.

Anyway, I discovered I do not have the patience for such things anymore.  If you do, then this game is a great classic.  Just be sure you are in the mood to play a very long, old school game or are ok with constantly googling the quest solutions.

reviewText:
As a hardcore RPG veteran, I'm telling you that this game is not like Baldur's Gate, Planescape Torment, an Elder Scrolls game, or any other classic you might like. If you're looking for something similar to one of those (like I was), don't buy Fallout 2.

I've tried nurmerous times to like Fallout 2. But each time it just utterly frustrates me.

Fallout 1 is a great game because of the dozens of ways you can build a character. In fact, it's not that hard to beat the game as a pacifist, relying on skills and such instead of fighting. It offers a true roleplaying experience and rewards creativity. It lets you roleplay the character that you want.

Fallout 2 is the opposite. It is based way too heavily on combat. Even on low difficulties, the fights are really hard. In addition, there are random encounters that happen while fast-traveling, that in addition to be very annoying and repetitive, also contribute to this difficulty problem. You basically get fatally punished for not making a perfect charatcer, and for exploring. The lattter of which defeats the purpose of an open-world game.

Playing a character that is focused around dealing with problems by using things like stealth, speech, or computers is impossible. Only heavily combat oriented characters can survive. But even if you optimize a character for combat, it's still ridiculously hard. I did exactly that (optimizing for combat) and still got 1-hit-killed by a gecko on easy after barely leaving the starting area, so I'm not exactly sure what kind of build is capable of beating this game.

Apparently, you can only play the developer's way rather than playing how you want to play. By not letting you play the ROLE you want, it completely defeats the purpose of ROLE PLAYING. And since it isn't fun and feels more like work, it isn't really a game.

So in conclusion, Fallout 2 neither role playing, nor is it a game.

reviewText: I started with Fallout 3. I'm not ashamed or anything this game came out before I even knew how to play video games. I still love Fallout 3 and the world Bethesda crafted for it. I've replayed it so much I know it like the back of my hand. Obviously being that there was a number 3 at the end of the title it got in my head to wonder What were the past games like? Fallout 3 has introduced me to a fantastic world and I want to see where it started!" Opun looking at screenshots I remember thinking "Wow... these games look old and crappy". However as time went on I actually played Half Life 1 for the first time which really open my naive eyes to the idea that "Hey! Just because it's old looking doesn't mean it sucks!" So I looked the games up again and decided on getting Fallout 2 over 1 as it said there was no time limit to 2.\n\nI can now say that I think Fallout 2 (and 1 respectively) is a far superiour game to Fallout 3. It's amazing how a game where many of the character sprites look the same and the world it self is clearly just 2D with an isometric view could get me so immersed. Being able to place plastic explosive at the foot of a door
recommended: then run like hell to watch it explode is just one of many things that made me fall in love with this game. While the gore and graphics of Fallout 3 are awesome being in a gunfight with raiders in Fallout 2 is even cooler. I've had a raider aim for my head only to miss and hit the other raider coming up behind me.\n\nFallout 2 is one of the few games that truly made me feel like a Wastleland Vigilante
hoursPlayed: like Mad Max and Clint Eastwood in one person. I did a mission for a town where I inspected a haunted farm only to find it inhabited by friendly ghouls. When I came back to the town the mayor told me if I didn't find one of their townfolks who had gone missing at the farm they would kill all the ghouls. When I couldn't find him I came back only to find that the mayor had really done it. He really killed all those innocents. So I shot him. I've never been so ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• at a fictional character in my life but unlike in a book or a movie I actually got to decide his fate and I decided his time was up.\n\nMy hope is that Fallout 4 will look back at some of these games and really try to implement some of the amazing player freedoms that this game allowed. If Fallout 4 ended up being and amazing 3d representation of this game my life would complete."

reviewText:
=======================Start 1: Torgue's Apprentice======================

Obtain some explosives
Arm those explosives
Then let someone to steal them from you (works best in crowded places)
Wait for timer to run out
Observe results

=======================Start 2: Beauty in a tin-can=======================

Meet Sergeant Dornan without advanced power armor
Listen to him while having your speakers\headphones at max volume
Get thy advanced power armor
Get laid while wearing advanced power armor
Become a porn star while wearing advanced power armor

=======================Start 3: I hate logic=============================

Get familiar with jinxed trait
Then find unlucky dog
Get double jinxed
Watch everyone fail miserably at their job

=======================Start 4: The stylish thief wasteland==================

Max out charisma and agility
Steal everything from everyone
Rinse and repeat the second part

=======================Start 5: Yough fren?============================

Set intelligence to 1 and Charisma to 10 or 1
Hngh?
Uhhh....

On serious note:
Start options listed above are just simple and wacky examples of what can be done just by creating character and playing the game.
Difficulty is somewhat rng'ish, for example you can meet very tough opponent in certain areas at start of the game but such are the wastes, harsh and unforgiving.
Gameplay is a perfect mix of strategy and rpg with rng for a good measure.
AI without mods is somewhat dumb, so don't get surprised if it does something wacky.
Visual part is something from 1995'ish but still pretty good.
Stability is kind of nice, it runs smooth and mostly stable on modern systems although not flawless (might be a few crashes here and there at certain points in the game).

Overall it's a great game but not flawless. Thankfully all of the irks and kinks can be fixed by mods.
If you were looking for a serious RPG with deep immersion and good story then this game is for you.

reviewText:
To be frank, I really enjoyed the game. I started playing it way after it was released, so this isn't a nostalgia trip for me or anything, this was from pure interest in the genre and what I've heard about it. I was not disappointed.

This game is packed with content. There's lots of quests, characters, weapons, locations, and items. There's almost always 2 or 3 ways to resolve a conflict and the straightest path isn't always the best one. Most of your choices do have some sort of consequence. The combat can be pretty challenging, but can also be like super easy if you have the right build, it's not particularly well balanced. The visuals, well, they kind of hit the spot for what the game is portraying. Dark, dull, forboding, if not boring landscapes. I mean, you're in the middle of the desert, it's not that interesting. The humor is pretty cool, and I must have laughed a few times at either something happening or when a character said something funny. The story is pretty interesting overall, having you start as one of the previous PC's (from Fallout) decendants in a tribal community to helping out (or hurting) towns or refugees to disabling (or enabling) nukes.

I think that anyone who can deal with turn-based rpgs should play this. It's pretty awesome. Even if you haven't played turn-based rpgs or maybe have had bad experiences with them, you should like this. But stay away if you can only handle fps style gameplay, this isn't for you.

The steam version does work with all of the mods out there btw, I've not run into any issues regarding that stuff.

10/10
Would die in the first battle again.

reviewText:
If you're a huge fan of the Fallout series, take a gander at this installment...

Pros:
1)Multiple friendly, humorous and diverse compainions to choose from.
2)For it's time, the graphics have intense messaging; you really get the sense that you're one of the few left in the wasteland.
3)A challenging plethora of side quest across many towns and settlements.
4)(Depending on hardware performance) Smooth and crisp tansitions between areas.
5)The only true loading screen you see is at the beginning.

Cons:
1)Somewhat reduntant encounters and brawls amongst semi-generic enemies.
2)Turn based combat leads to a back and forth, stimpack filled feud with the smallest of creatures.
3)Even with the inclusion of a push back" button for NPCs and companions
date:
you'll always find yourself cramped in a large area.
4) Dying isn't fun in any game; this game reinforces that statement to a broad point.
5)The occasional framerate drop when entering a new area may force you to restart the game.

With those points in mind

reviewText:
What a wonderful game.

Here are some pro-tips for beginners I wish I'd known at the start:

1)  In the first dungeon, the Temple of Trials, you're going to be forced to melee.  Everything in here (ants and scorpions) can be kited if you have at least 7 action points.  Punch something (using 3), and move 4 spaces away from it.  It will use all of its action points to close the 4 space gap, and not be able to attack you.  This will save you a lot of trouble.

2)  You can heal yourself using doctor/first aid skills in addition to the powder.  This can only be done successfully three times each though.  (Save your antidotes if poisoned, you'll be able to cure the poison with the use of these skills and/or it will wear off over the course of the time it takes you to attempt to use them)

3)  When you enter the second area, walk slowly forward, one space at a time.  As you notice the raised stone plates, use the traps skill on them.  Even if you skill is low, keep using it.  Eventually, you'll disarm them, for 25 XP each.

4)  You can steal the key from the final guy to avoid fighting him.  You can keep reloading if your steal skill is low.  Alternatively you can talk him out of the fight if you have enough speech skill.

5)  If you level up in the dungeon, don't put points into melee or unarmed. There's a trainer for each in the first village.  If you have less than 55% unarmed skill, you can train to 55%.  There's a guy for melee weapons too, that'll give you +10%.  I'm not sure what the cutoff is.

reviewText:
Hey, a Fallout game! The first one was fun, and since I've beat all of them but 2, this'll be a piece of cake, right?

No. No it will not. This game will murder you over and over and over and over again. If you don't make every choice right this game will rip your arm off an beat you with it, you will know this game inside and out, be able to redraw the map like it was tattooed into your brain. This game is hard to say the least, but is also fun.

Pros: Don't get me wrong when I say fun, it's kind of like mowing the lawn for the first time, exciting and you can't wait to do more, but constantly worrying that you'll do it wrong and it'll come back to bite you in the future. Story wise, fantastic. Better than all the others and than some. Also lots of crazy easter eggs and references so be prepared.

Cons: Sometimes the game just decides to kill itself and have seizures, but it was made in the 1990's so I'll forgive it.

Final thoughts: If you consider yourself a fan of the Fallout series you have to play this. And you should. But if you're asking yourself I thought Fallout 3 was the first fallout game" or

reviewText:
What a wonderful game.

Here are some pro-tips for beginners I wish I'd known at the start:

1)  In the first dungeon, the Temple of Trials, you're going to be forced to melee.  Everything in here (ants and scorpions) can be kited if you have at least 7 action points.  Punch something (using 3), and move 4 spaces away from it.  It will use all of its action points to close the 4 space gap, and not be able to attack you.  This will save you a lot of trouble.

2)  You can heal yourself using doctor/first aid skills in addition to the powder.  This can only be done successfully three times each though.  (Save your antidotes if poisoned, you'll be able to cure the poison with the use of these skills and/or it will wear off over the course of the time it takes you to attempt to use them)

3)  When you enter the second area, walk slowly forward, one space at a time.  As you notice the raised stone plates, use the traps skill on them.  Even if you skill is low, keep using it.  Eventually, you'll disarm them, for 25 XP each.

4)  You can steal the key from the final guy to avoid fighting him.  You can keep reloading if your steal skill is low.  Alternatively you can talk him out of the fight if you have enough speech skill.

5)  If you level up in the dungeon, don't put points into melee or unarmed. There's a trainer for each in the first village.  If you have less than 55% unarmed skill, you can train to 55%.  There's a guy for melee weapons too, that'll give you +10%.  I'm not sure what the cutoff is.

reviewText:
To be frank, I really enjoyed the game. I started playing it way after it was released, so this isn't a nostalgia trip for me or anything, this was from pure interest in the genre and what I've heard about it. I was not disappointed.

This game is packed with content. There's lots of quests, characters, weapons, locations, and items. There's almost always 2 or 3 ways to resolve a conflict and the straightest path isn't always the best one. Most of your choices do have some sort of consequence. The combat can be pretty challenging, but can also be like super easy if you have the right build, it's not particularly well balanced. The visuals, well, they kind of hit the spot for what the game is portraying. Dark, dull, forboding, if not boring landscapes. I mean, you're in the middle of the desert, it's not that interesting. The humor is pretty cool, and I must have laughed a few times at either something happening or when a character said something funny. The story is pretty interesting overall, having you start as one of the previous PC's (from Fallout) decendants in a tribal community to helping out (or hurting) towns or refugees to disabling (or enabling) nukes.

I think that anyone who can deal with turn-based rpgs should play this. It's pretty awesome. Even if you haven't played turn-based rpgs or maybe have had bad experiences with them, you should like this. But stay away if you can only handle fps style gameplay, this isn't for you.

The steam version does work with all of the mods out there btw, I've not run into any issues regarding that stuff.

10/10
Would die in the first battle again.

reviewText:
If you're a huge fan of the Fallout series, take a gander at this installment...

Pros:
1)Multiple friendly, humorous and diverse compainions to choose from.
2)For it's time, the graphics have intense messaging; you really get the sense that you're one of the few left in the wasteland.
3)A challenging plethora of side quest across many towns and settlements.
4)(Depending on hardware performance) Smooth and crisp tansitions between areas.
5)The only true loading screen you see is at the beginning.

Cons:
1)Somewhat reduntant encounters and brawls amongst semi-generic enemies.
2)Turn based combat leads to a back and forth, stimpack filled feud with the smallest of creatures.
3)Even with the inclusion of a push back" button for NPCs and companions
date:
you'll always find yourself cramped in a large area.
4) Dying isn't fun in any game; this game reinforces that statement to a broad point.
5)The occasional framerate drop when entering a new area may force you to restart the game.

With those points in mind
